It's been a good start to the summer for Manchester United, with arrivals secured in the two priority positions identified before the window opened to freshen up Erik ten Hag's squad.

A forward and a centre-back were considered the most pressing issues after the departures of Raphael Varane and Anthony Martial on free transfers. In Leny Yoro and Joshua Zirkzee they have young replacements on much lower salaries. Ten Hag is certainly pleased with the business done and praised the new football structure in place at United when speaking after the pre-season friendly win against Rangers on Saturday.
"I think at the moment the football leadership is very on the front foot. I think that's what clubs like Manchester United should do," he said.

The signs are encouraging under the leadership of sporting director Dan Ashworth, technical director Jason Wilcox and interim director of recruitment Christopher Vivell, but the window could get more challenging from here on in. The work is certainly not done for United. A deal for Matthijs de Ligt remains likely if a centre-back is sold, while they could for a full-back if Aaron Wan-Bissaka departs.

Then there is the midfield. A new holding midfielder is now a priority for United and although that doesn't entirely depend on sales, it would clearly grease the cogs when it comes to freeing up funds.

So far Casemiro has started both pre-season friendlies in a deep midfield role without looking much sharper than last season. As one of the squad's highest earners Ineos are keen to move him on, but there has been limited interest so far and at the moment the Brazilian is expecting to stay.

If flogging the five-time Champions League winner proves to be beyond United, then they might have to consider cashing in on Scott McTominay. Ten Hag said he wanted to keep him on Saturday, but he was never likely to say otherwise and was happy to sell him a year ago.

Any fee for the academy graduate would be pocketed as pure profit in accounting terms for PSR, so the advantages are understandable. There might be more of a willingness to sell McTominay after Mason Mount made an impressive start to pre-season.

They also hold an interest in Arsenal target Martin Zubimendi. The 25-year-old came off the bench for Rodri in the Euro 2024 final and has a €60m (£50.5m) release clause in his Real Sociedad contract.

headline: 'A legend' - Leny Yoro reveals surprise phone call that helped convince him to join Man United
body: Leny Yoro signed for Manchester United for £58.9m and the move came as a surprise after he attracted the interest of Real Madrid during the summer.

Former Manchester United centre-back Rio Ferdinand called Leny Yoro to convince the teenager to sign for the club, the teenager has revealed.
United had been courting Yoro since the end of last season and held meetings with the 18-year-old to explain their plans to him, while Erik ten Hag also spoke to the central defender.

Real Madrid had long been expected to complete a deal for Yoro this summer but United's groundwork paid off when they had an offer of £58.9m accepted by Lille, while Ferdinand also turned on the charm offensive.

Ferdinand called Yoro and sold him on the benefits of a move to United and the defender, who made the Ligue 1 team of the year last season, revealed the conversation with the six-time Premier League winner played a key role in convincing him to join the club.

"This is Rio Ferdinand, this is a legend in Man United, so for me this is an honour. This is a big defender, a legend, so yeah, big honour for me," Yoro said in his first in-depth interview with MUTV.

"It was like two weeks ago. He called me, so first of all I was really impressed to speak with him and yeah, we spoke like 10 minutes about Man United, so he helped me a lot to make my choice. So yeah, it was really an honour to speak with him.

"He spoke to me about the club, and [that] this is a historic club with a big story, and if I go there I need to fight for the club, to be ready, because this is the biggest club in the world. So, yeah, for me it was really good to speak about this."
Yoro revealed he had watched Ferdinand playing for United as a child and reflected on the quality of defenders who had gone before him in that era.
"When I was younger, Rio was one of the best defenders in the world. I think everyone watched United when he was young and, for me, it was a dream to play for this club," he said.
"Only big defenders in this team! Yeah, it's really crazy that United have big defenders like this. It's really crazy."

With just over three weeks to go until the start of the new Premier League season, the number of players who are being linked with moves to Manchester United is increasing.

United made their second signing of the summer last week, drafting in highly-rated centre-back Leny Yoro from Lille. The Reds saw off competition from Real Madrid to sign the Frenchman and he impressed on his debut against Rangers on Saturday.

Joshua Zirkzee is the club's only other new arrival so far in this window, but United are working tirelessly behind the scenes to add more quality to Erik ten Hag's squad. It is understood the addition of a new midfielder is now their next objective.

United want to draft in a new defensive-minded midfielder to operate at the base of the engine room and have been heavily linked with Paris Saint-Germain's Manuel Ugarte. They have also expressed interest in Real Sociedad's Martin Zubimendi.

Despite the addition of a holding midfielder being United's main aim in relation to their quest to strengthen their midfield options, they have been credited with interest in Paris Saint-Germain midfielder Xavi Simons. The Netherlands international is an attack-minded midfielder, recognised for playing as a No.10. He can also operate out wide, either on the right or the left.

According to Transfermarkt, Simons, who spent last season on loan at German club RB Leipzig, made 41 of his 43 appearances last term as a wide player, starting just two games centrally. United are currently knee-deep in wingers, meaning it is hard to envision them wanting to sign him to operate out wide.

Nevertheless, reports overseas suggest the 21-year-old, who scored for the Netherlands in their European Championship semi-final defeat to England earlier this month, is at the centre of a transfer tug-of-war, with Bayern Munich and Barcelona also being credited with interest in his services.

Prior to last season's stint at Leipzig, Simons spent the 2022/23 campaign on loan at PSV Eindhoven, where Ruud van Nistelrooy was the manager. The Dutchman recently joined United as one of Ten Hag's new assistants.

Simons starred under Van Nistelrooy's management, scoring 20 goals and creating 12 in 46 games in all competitions. Although his attacking output impressed the former PSV boss, it was his mentality that pleased Van Nistelrooy most.

Speaking to Voetbal International in September 2022, Van Nistelrooy said of Simons: "His mentality, his mindset, it's unprecedented. It's a boy of only 19 years old, but Xavi is already much further advanced than his age.
"But he really is a pure professional, a boy who is working towards a goal, who wants to get the most out of his qualities."
He added: "He's doing everything he can to get to the top, his top. And where that will be, that's the beautiful challenge.
"That bit in him, wanting to do everything for that, I recognise that from myself as a player. I can only enjoy that."

The former United striker quickly developed an understanding of his mentality and that is a key trait Ten Hag analyses when drawing up recruitment plans.

body: Man United are still looking to sign another centre-half in the summer transfer window as their squad rebuild continues

Manchester United's capture of exciting teenager Leny Yoro is only one part of their aim to transform their defence this summer.

The Reds spent big to entice Yoro from Lille, beating Real Madrid to the 18-year-old's signature after a fee that could rise to £58.9m was agreed with the French outfit. Yoro then made his debut on Saturday, impressing over 45 minutes against Rangers.

United, however, are not finished there with their central defensive makeover. Having finished last season in eighth position and with a negative goal difference, Erik ten Hag and Ineos are determined to improve most areas of the squad.

Yoro is a replacement for fellow Frenchman Raphael Varane, who left Old Trafford when his contract expired. However, United want at least one more centre-half - potentially two - in a bid to get back into the Premier League's top four.

Jarrad Branthwaite and Matthijs de Ligt both remain firm targets. United have had two bids for Branthwaite rejected while they have agreed personal terms with Dutchman De Ligt, but are yet to settle on a fee with his club Bayern Munich.

The deal for De Ligt looks likely to happen at some point this summer, but former United striker Teddy Sheringham has urged Ineos to move on from the player and instead swoop for Crystal Palace defender Marc Guehi. The England man has been linked with a move to United over the last month, while Arsenal are also reportedly interested in him.

Guehi excelled at Euro 2024, taking the place of the injured Harry Maguire alongside John Stones in Gareth Southgate's starting line-up. And Sheringham believes the 24-year-old is a better option than the other players being scouted.
"Manchester United should go for Marc Guehi over Matthijs de Ligt," he told OLBG. "United don’t need big name players they need hard graft and players who will put a shift in week in and week out.
"From what I’ve seen of Guehi, especially this summer, he’d be a great addition at Old Trafford."
Sheringham isn't the only fan of the Palace man. Manchester City and England winger Phil Foden recently hailed Guehi's leadership qualities after his stellar performances at the Euros.

"'He [Guehi] has been a leader," he said on the official England team's YouTube channel. "I know him well from obviously playing with him and he's not fazed by anything. I feel like he has come into the team and shown his qualities."

United's lack of leadership last season was criticised by a number of players, including Wayne Rooney. And Ten Hag has admitted he wants a better culture and spirit in the United dressing room. It's a view echoed by Sheringham.
"Manchester United need to sign top players all over the pitch. They haven't got any leaders at the club. They need leaders but they don't come cheap," he added.
"Top players, leaders on the football pitch, that's why when they do become available, like last summer in Harry Kane and Declan Rice, they should have been in for them."

headline: Man United's midfield transfer dilemma - Zubimendi interest, Amrabat decision and Rabiot chance
body: Man Utd are mulling over whether to sign Martin Zubimendi, Manuel Ugarte, Adrien Rabiot or Sofyan Amrabat to boost their midfield options.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info

The wheels are in motion for Manchester United this summer - with Leny Yoro and Joshua Zirkzee now on board - as INEOS plot further additions behind the scenes. A third incoming is edging closer for United as they continue to run the rule over four midfield options including Euro 2024 winner Martin Zubimendi.
Manuel Ugarte and Adrien Rabiot are also on radar, while a return for Sofyan Amrabat hasn't been ruled out, either.

United have started discussions with PSG over Ugarte - who only joined the French outfit last summer - while free agent Rabiot has long-since been linked with a move to Old Trafford. Interest in Zubimendi is relatively fresh after a coming-of-age season with Real Sociedad preceded Euro 2024 glory at England's expense in Berlin.
There are pros and cons to each of the options above. Here, our team of reporters share their thoughts;

It is very clear that Manchester United need to and likely will sign a new defensive midfielder. Despite the emergence of Kobbie Mainoo, United's midfield issues are well known with Erik ten Hag making a surprise tactical change which saw Bruno Fernandes deployed in a false nine role in an attempt to solve those problems.

With the hope of avoiding doing that again, United are looking at several midfielders with Ineos identifying a number of targets. Joao Neves, Adrien Rabiot and Manuel Ugarte have all been linked with Real Sociedad's Martin Zubimendi the latest name to emerge of interest.

Arsenal are also admirers of Zubimendi, however that is no longer present with it seen as likely the 25-year-old remains in Spain. As for Ugarte and Neves, both Paris Saint-Germain and Benfica are expected to command sizeable fees with it intriguing PSG are looking at Neves as a potential replacement for Ugarte.

Sofyan Amrabat meanwhile, impressed in the latter weeks of the last season with United having the option to make his loan permanent for just over £20million. Considering how he performed in several decisive games for United, alongside Ineos' eagerness to not overspend, bringing Amrabat back to Old Trafford should be completed.

Manchester United's transfer business so far has looked promising with deals for young and talented players completed swiftly. It's a far cry from previous windows under Ed Woodward and John Murtough.

And a deal for Manuel Ugarte should be next on their list. Yes, the Uruguayan struggled at PSG but aged 23, he shouldn't be written off after just one season, particularly when he shone in the Champions League for Sporting just two seasons ago.

Whilst Sofyan Amrabat impressed at times towards the end of 2023/24, I don't think he's demonstrated enough throughout his career to be considered good enough for what United want to be. He was dealt a bad hand at times with United's injury crisis forcing him to play out of position but I don't think he's good enough.

Adrien Rabiot is an interesting one. At his best, he is an asset to any team but I'm unsure how often we'll see that and United can't afford to sign another inconsistent midfielder. Ultimately, Ugarte is the one they need to sign and we're then looking at a very good window.

Budget will be the buzzword from here on this summer. Yoro and Zirkzee have arrived to plug two much-needed gaps for the present and future - at either end - with further centre-back additions planned. The deals to get them to Old Trafford have been calculated, precise and effective to offer up hope for INEOS control.

However, there are a few moving parts at play when it comes to the engine room, meaning the best option might not be the most practical or attainable. Funds, who moves on and what United actually want from a new defensive midfielder is not set in stone, but Zubimendi does represent an intriguing proposition.

As shown by his Euro 2024 showpiece appearance - when replacing injured Manchester City talisman Rodri at half-time - the Sociedad man is technically brilliant, tactically aware and defensively sound. He might not have the same physically as Ugarte, for example, but his ability on the ball could fit perfectly into the style Ten Hag wants.
If money were no object, Zubimendi might just be the one to allow United to evolve this season.

It’s been a summer of bringing young talent to United so far with the arrivals of Joshua Zirkzee and Leny Yoro. It should be the same with the club looking to strengthen their midfield for the upcoming season.

Defensive midfield is the priority area, especially considering the reports surrounding United not making Sofyan Amrabat’s move permanent. Manuel Ugarte is the name that has probably been the most heavily linked, while he hasn’t had too much success at Paris Saint Germain, at just 23-years-old he has plenty of time to prove what he can do.

Another interesting name is Adrien Rabiot, who is available on a free transfer following his exit from Juventus. While he would be the cheaper option in terms of a fee, he would demand bigger wages and see United move away from signing young, up-and-coming players.

Rabiot is a more attacking option and could cover both the defensive midfield position as well as providing competition further forward. But I feel that opting for Ugarte would be a better long-term choice.

United may have to spend shrewdly for the remainder of the summer until they can offload several players who have become surplus to requirements under the new regime. That is why Rabiot represents an opportunity they should seriously consider.

While the France international was one of Juventus' highest earners before his contract expired, the chance to sign a player with his experience and versatility on a free transfer is not one to pass up. Rabiot does not turn 30 until early April and has shown no signs of slowing down over recent seasons.

The midfielder made at least 35 appearances across all competitions during all five seasons in Turin and has avoided major injuries throughout his career. Capable of playing in defensive midfield or a more traditional role in the middle - and even wide on the left at a push - the Parisian would be a welcome addition to Erik ten Hag's squad.

PSG have arguably failed to replace the academy graduate since he left in 2019, which, in a roundabout way, led them to sign Ugarte last summer, a move that went so well they are willing to sell 12 months later. United must not make the same mistake.

headline: £17m FFP option, full-back poser, De Ligt upgrade - Man United squad stocktake after huge transfer
body: Man United have added Leny Yoro and Joshua Zirkzee to their squad so far this summer, but a lot more work still needs to be done ahead of the transfer deadline.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United strengthened their defensive options with the signing of Lille centre-back Leny Yoro in midweek. It was a huge deal for the club, beating Real Madrid to his signature.

The 18-year-old finalised his switch to Old Trafford on Thursday and put pen to paper on a five-year deal. He became the club's second signing of the summer, following in the footsteps of Joshua Zirkzee.

The youngster has immediately strengthened United's centre-back options, but the club is open to making more additions in the heart of the defence. It is one of a handful of areas they could still add to this summer.
With that in mind, MEN Sport has taken a close look at how United's squad looks as it currently stands and what might change before the window closes in our audit of the player inventory.

United are currently well-stocked in the goalkeeping department after tying Tom Heaton down to a new contract earlier this month. Andre Onana will continue as the club's No.1 this season and it is likely he will be supported by Altay Bayindir, who played just once last term after arriving from Fenerbahce.

Beyond Onana, Bayindir and Heaton, United also have the likes of Radek Vitek, Dermot Mee and Elyh Harrison who can provide even more depth. It would be no great surprise to see Vitek head out on loan again after his excellent performance against Rosenborg.

Following the capture of Yoro, United's level of strength in depth across all areas of the back four is currently reasonable, with the Frenchman joining Lisandro Martinez, Harry Maguire, Victor Lindelof and Jonny Evans at centre-back. However, United are keen to offload Lindelof and that could open the door for a replacement.

Erik ten Hag has confirmed the club's interest in Bayern Munich's Matthijs de Ligt and United have already agreed personal terms with him. Bringing him in and shipping Lindelof out would be an upgrade, and would leave the club with a strong collection of central defenders.

In the full-back areas, United will only strengthen at right-back if Aaron Wan-Bissaka is moved on. His contract is up in just under a year's time and he has been linked with clubs both domestically and overseas.

At left-back, last season's long-term injuries to both Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia could force United's hand to bring in another option, but they have youngsters Sam Murray and Harry Amass showing plenty of promise and they could make up the numbers.

If they are fit and available for selection, Kobbie Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes will be two of the very first names on the teamsheet. Fernandes is United's captain and chief creator, while Mainoo is an undroppable figure.

The need for a defensive midfielder to complete Ten Hag's ideal midfield trio is no secret. Casemiro regressed last season and United need a younger operator in that area of the pitch. They still need to replace Sofryan Amrabat too, whose loan spell came to an end.

In an ideal world, United could do with selling Casemiro before his value plummets further. In a stocktake of United's inventory, this one is pushing close to the best before date. Mason Mount will be hoping for an injury-free second season at Old Trafford to prove his worth and Scott McTominay could be retained after a haul of 10 goals last season, but a tempting offer could convince them to sell.

Christian Eriksen and Hannibal Mejbri are still on the books and can operate as No.8s. Both are out of contract next summer and could be moved on to avoid losing them for free. Hannibal, in particular, would provide United with a significant PSR boost, having come through the academy since joining from Monaco in 2019 aged just 16. His loan spell at Spanish side Sevilla featured an option for the LaLiga club to sign him permanently this summer for £17m but after he failed to impress, United have missed out on that FFP windfall.
If United cut them both from their squad, they will need replacing. United will admit they need to trim the squad in places, but they cannot leave themselves short.

Speaking of wingers, if United need to trim any department within their squad this summer it has to be the wide areas. Ten Hag is knee-deep in wingers who can operate on either flank. There is plenty of surplus stock that could be sold to help reinvest.

Alejandro Garnacho, Facundo Pellistri, Jadon Sancho, Antony and Amad are all vying for the right-wing berth, while Marcus Rashford's future on the left is far from certain. Both Garnacho and Sancho can play on either side to compete with Rashford.

Sancho, despite clearing the air with Ten Hag, could still be offloaded, while Pellistri needs to go for the good of his own career. It means Garnacho and Rashford are primed to start on the flanks, supported by Amad and Antony.
United moved fast to replace Anthony Martial, bringing in Zirkzee from Bologna. He will provide support and competition for Rasmus Hojlund, who is expected to remain the club's first-choice striker.

Ten Hag operates with a system that features just one centre-forward, meaning Hojlund is expected to remain top of the pecking order, with Zirkzee providing cover from the bench. There is still talk of another striker being signed this summer, but it is not a leading priority.

body: Man United youngster Toby Collyer has made progress in the academy and has been given a prominent role in pre-season.

Erik ten Hag believes Manchester United youngster Toby Collyer has 'earned' his opportunity to get first-team minutes.
Collyer was given the captain's armband in the second half of the opening pre-season clash against Rosenborg and he started against Rangers this weekend.
The midfielder started alongside Casemiro and Mason Mount and is set to be included in the travelling squad for the upcoming pre-season tour of the United States.

Earlier this month, Collyer signed a new contract with United until 2027 and Ten Hag insisted on attending his signing ceremony at Carrington. The Dutchman was also spotted deep in conversation with Collyer after the FA Cup final and is understood to 'really like' him.

Ten Hag took time to speak to a handful of Manchester-based reporters after Saturday's friendly victory over Rangers and he was asked for his opinion on Collyer. "You know me, I always want to make pathways for young players but they have to earn it," said Ten Hag.

"He's now earned an opportunity. Today he was in the starting XI, that's something, and we see how we can progress. We saw last year with [Alejandro] Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo what can happen, so the pathway is also open for other players and Toby is there in fourth."
It's believed Ten Hag was suggesting Collyer would be the 'fourth' academy player to contribute to the first-team squad after Garnacho, Mainoo and Willy Kambwala.

Ten Hag has overseen the development of Garnacho and Mainoo and both youngsters are now established first-team players. They both scored in the 2-1 victory in the FA Cup final over Manchester City at Wembley and are now playing senior international football.
Kambwala enjoyed a breakthrough last season but was sold to Villarreal this summer in a deal worth €11.5m, which was considered a transfer fee too big to reject.
Collyer was named on the bench eight times last season and although he didn't make the squad for the FA Cup final, he travelled to Wembley and was on the pitch at full-time.
Ten Hag speaking to Collyer on the pitch at Wembley has drawn comparisons to his conversation with Mainoo after United won the Carabao Cup in February 2023.
Collyer is yet to make his first-team debut but is not expected to go out on loan this season, which suggests he could become the next player to make his senior bow.
United signed Collyer from the Brighton academy in 2022 and he trained under Ten Hag in September 2022.

headline: Sancho sale, £120m deals, Rashford boost - Man United's 40 days and 40 nights of transfer window
body: The clock is ticking on the transfer window and Manchester United are set to be extremely busy.

Manchester United's transfer business has ramped up over the last week - but it is only set to get busier as Ineos continue what could be a remarkable rebuild of the first-team squad.

Leny Yoro's arrival from Lille for £58.9million was completed just a few days after Joshua Zirkzee arrived from Bologna for £35.7m. They are the first two signings of the Ineos era but won't be the last.

United will look to add more players to the squad this summer to give Erik ten Hag's side a boost after what was a dismal league campaign. And while the summer sales have already begun, there will also be more outgoings with several players heading for the exit door.
READ MORE:Erik ten Hag makes transfer demand
There are 40 days and 40 nights left until the transfer window closes at 11pm on August 30. We take a look at what could happen between now and then.

It's shaping up to be one of the greatest comebacks since the 1999 Champions League final. Jadon Sancho, sent on loan to Borussia Dortmund after a savage fall-out with Erik ten Hag, looked to have no future at Old Trafford, only for the pair to bury the hatchet last week.

Sancho, remarkably, then started at the weekend against Rangers, but doubts still persist over whether he has a long-term future at the club under the Dutchman. There would be few people surprised if the winger had departed the club before the transfer deadline, either on loan or permanently. Interest remains from clubs in Serie A, including Juventus, while Dortmund can't be ruled out from making another move.

At one stage last season it looked like Rashford would be on his way this summer. An alarming drop in form and indiscipline - including being fined for an unauthorised night out in Belfast - had seen the forward's stock drop, not just in Ten Hag's eyes but also in those of some United matchgoers.

Arsenal and Paris St Germain have both been linked with a move for the striker. The Manchester Evening News reported earlier this month that the player was set for talks with the United hierarchy with his future still uncertain.

Since then, there has been little speculation about Rashford. He remains off social media, and started Monday's pre-season game at Rosenborg. He will be hoping that he can recapture the form that saw him hit 30 goals in the 2022-23 season and force his way back into the England reckoning.
Whether that is with United or elsewhere will be seen after August 30.

Now, firstly some apologies on this one. It could actually be that United have longer than 40 days to seal this deal with the Saudi Pro League's transfer window not closing until September 2. United would still want a deal wrapped up well before that, however, so they know what position they are in financially and for finding a replacement.

Casemiro suffered a difficult campaign, looking a shadow of the player who set the standards at United in his first season at the club, and 100 miles away from the force who won multiple Champions Leagues with Real Madrid.
United are keen to cash in, but may have to lower their £30m asking price. Saudi interest has gone quiet but still remains - it will just take a bit of time to agree on contract, fee and demands.

Another centre-back and a midfielder are likely additions this summer, with one player in those areas likely to be sold. A full-back could also be pursued if Aaron Wan-Bissaka leaves the club, with Premier League interest in the former Crystal Palace right-back.

United could potentially need two midfielders, regardless of what happens to Casemiro. Sofyan Amrabat's loan came to an end and while a return for the Moroccan hasn't been entirely ruled out, there are other options.

If a senior midfielder does depart, United will push ahead to bring in a new addition this summer, having held talks with Paris St-Germain over Uruguay international Manuel Ugarte, who is keen to make the switch. There is also interest in Real Sociedad's Spanish international Martin Zubimendi. However, a move for Benfica's highly-rated teenager Joao Neves looks to have hit the buffers due to his price tag, with PSG now seemingly in pole position.

United are now in a position where they need to sell to raise funds. The transfer budget was limited this summer and reliant on bringing in money by selling players, with offers listened to for everyone bar four - Andre Onana, Kobbie Mainoo, Alejandro Garnacho and Rasmus Hojlund.

Peripheral members of Ten Hag's squad such as Victor Lindelof, Christian Eriksen and even potentially Harry Maguire could be moved on. And there will be no space in the squad for Facundo Pellistri and Hannibal Mejbri. United missed out on a £17m windfall when Sevilla failed to take up the option to sign Hannibal permanently after his loan spell, and with just a year left on his deal United will hope they can still get a good sum for him this summer. Pellistri, meanwhile, is interesting Greek side Panathinaikos.

United have already brought in more than £40m from the combined sales of Mason Greenwood, Willy Kambwala and Donny van de Beek but will need to raise a lot more before 11pm on August 30. If they can get £35m for Sancho, £20m for Casemiro and £25m for the combined sales of Pellistri and Hannibal, it will have added £120m to the budget.

headline: Man United transfer decision made as clear Ivan Toney warning fired
body: The latest Manchester United transfer news as we take a look at some of the stories around the club over the past 24 hours as the transfer window continues

Pre-season is well underway, meaning that there is not long to go until the 2024/25 campaign is upon us.

Manchester United were in friendly action on Saturday as they came out as 2-0 winners against Rangers. Eyes now turn to the USA tour as Erik ten Hag prepares his team for what will be another long Premier League season.

Back in Manchester, work will be going on around transfers. United have added striker Joshua Zirkzee and defender Leny Yoro to their squad so far, but have been linked with several other players including midfielder Manuel Ugarte and defender Matthijs de Ligt.

There has also been talk over who could leave the club before the transfer deadline next month. Fringe players could potentially move on in search of game time with any money raised possibly boosting the funds available for incomings.
Here’s a look at a couple of stories from in and around Old Trafford over the past 24 hours. We’ve also given our own view on the situation.

The agent of United winger Antony has said that his client plans on staying with the club beyond the transfer window, amid speculation over his future. It has been reported that United could consider sending the Brazilian out on loan this summer, if his wages are paid.
But Junior Pedroso, Antony’s representative has poured cold water on that suggestion. He told Fabrizio Romano: “I see reports about potential exit on loan. Antony’s plan is clear: Manchester United”.
“He wants to stay, he’s only focused on Man United. We already spoke about that with the club”.

MEN Sport says: It’s always nice to hear that a player wants to stay at the club and fight for their place in the team, but after a season to forget a move away from United, even if only on loan may be just what Antony needs. The emergence of Amad, who will be looking for more regular starts this season, plus the return of Jadon Sancho, who could now stay at the club after making up with Ten Hag, only adds to the competition on the wings.
If Antony can’t get regular game time, then he’s going to find it hard to play himself into form. That will only reduce his value and make any sale in upcoming transfer windows harder.

Brentford manager Thomas Frank has given an update on striker Ivan Toney. The England man has just one year remaining on his contract with the club with admissions made earlier in the season over him being sold this summer.
United have previously been linked with an interest in Toney, but Frank has warned that any deal will be ‘expensive’ for the buying club.
“You never know. He’s a Brentford player and I would love him to stay,” he said. “That would give me a very positive challenge.

“But I haven’t met a coach who doesn’t want as many good players as possible. Right now, Ivan is a Brentford player. I would be more than happy if he stayed with us. He’s a goalscorer and that’s very good to have in your team so if you want to buy him, it’s expensive.”

MEN Sport says: If United hadn’t have signed Joshua Zirkzee earlier this month, then Toney would be a brilliant signing. But the arrival of the Dutchman means that United now have no need for another striker, especially one that is going to eat into the transfer budget further.
Toney showed what he can do in his short cameo against Slovakia for England in the Euros. He also does it week-in, week-out for Brentford in the Premier League.
The striker would be a clever signing for a club on the lookout for a striker who is a proven goalscorer in the league, but United should concentrate on other areas of the pitch.

headline: Perfect Kobbie Mainoo partner signs and £15m exit - Man United's dream squad after pre-season
body: Manchester United have more work to do in this summer's transfer window following the arrivals of Joshua Zirkzee and Leny Yoro.

Manchester United will step up their pre-season preparations when they travel to the United States on Wednesday for their pre-season tour.

The Reds will play three friendlies during their stay in the US, facing Arsenal, Real Betis and Liverpool. Each outing will help Erik ten Hag's players prepare for the season opener against Manchester City in the Community Shield at Wembley on August 10.

Alongside preparing for the new season on the pitch, United are working tirelessly off it to provide Ten Hag with all the tools he needs. After signing Joshua Zirkzee from Bologna last Sunday, Leny Yoro arrived from Lille on Thursday.

United entered this summer's transfer window with the ambition of strengthening both up front and at centre-back. To have achieved both of those objectives before flying out to the US deserves recognition.

However, United are not done yet, with the addition of a defensive midfielder still a leading objective. They are also still open to bringing in at least one more centre-back, while further additions in other areas cannot be dismissed.
United will also want to increase their number of outgoings. They have so far offloaded Alvaro Fernandez, Willy Kambwala, Donny van de Beek and Mason Greenwood.

To complete their 25-man squad for the forthcoming season, United need to oversee more wheeling and dealing. Ten Hag wants to increase the level of quality throughout his squad and that means assembling an improved level of depth.

Starting with the goalkeeping department, United, barring any unexpected developments, are all set in that area of the team, with Altay Bayindir and Tom Heaton primed to provide support for first-choice shot-stopper Andre Onana. The Cameroonian improved as last season unfolded and there is very little chance of him being dislodged at the top of the pecking order.

Aaron Wan-Bissaka's contract situation creates a puzzle at right-back. The former Crystal Palace man has entered the final 12 months of his current deal and that represents an opportunity for United to cash in and get money in the pot. A fee of £15million has been mooted as being enough to convince United to let go of the man they spent £50m on back in 2019.

Diogo Dalot deserves to remain United's first-choice right-back but would need a degree of competition if Wan-Bissaka is sold. Denzel Dumfries has once again been linked with a move to Old Trafford but he would expect to start every week.

The Reds have acted swiftly to replace Raphael Varane, bringing in Yoro. The highly-rated 18-year-old is a statement signing and he will expect to start alongside Lisandro Martinez at the heart of the back four.

United, despite wanting to add another centre-back, are now well-stocked in that area of the team. However, the Reds want to sell Victor Lindelof, meaning it could prove to be a case of shipping the Swede out and bringing Matthijs de Ligt in.

At left-back, Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia will be hoping to put an injury-hit 2023/24 campaign behind them and make up for lost time. The former, if he maintains his fitness, will start most games, but Malacia's fragility means United could benefit from another left-back addition.
Harry Amass and Sam Murray are both showing signs of promise, but their inexperience could convince United to bring in another option for the left side of the defence.
The defensive midfield berth needs fresh legs before the window closes. Casemiro regressed last season and Sofyan Amrabat has returned to Fiorentina after his season-long loan spell.

Paris Saint-Germain's Manuel Ugarte has been identified as an option to succeed Casemiro, who could be sold amid his surprise downfall. If he is shipped out, United would need to bring in an additional defensive midfielder to ensure they have two players vying for that role, meaning you cannot rule out the possibility of Amrabat returning.

Elsewhere in midfield, Mason Mount will be hoping to put a forgettable first season at Old Trafford behind him and kick on, but Hannibal Mejbri is in danger of being moved on ahead of his contract expiring next summer. Christian Eriksen is in the same boat and could also depart if a suitor comes calling.

Kobbie Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes are guaranteed starters, with the latter pulling the strings in the attacking midfield role. Scott McTominay, who could be sold if the right offer comes along, can provide cover in that attacking role.

United are currently knee-deep in wingers. Facundo Pellistri needs moving on for the good of his own career and it remains to be seen if Jadon Sancho will be able to rekindle his career at Old Trafford after patching things up with Ten Hag.
United have strengthened their striker options by adding Zirkzee to their ranks. He will provide support and competition for Rasmus Hojlund in the centre of the front three.

body: Man United boss Erik ten Hag will be hoping to strengthen his squad further after the additions of Joshua Zirkzee and Leny Yoro

Aaron Wan-Bissaka continues to be linked with a move to Manchester United, with the full-back's contract set to expire next year.

Wan-Bissaka has been at Old Trafford since 2019 and has served United well, even if he splits opinions among fans. However, the 26-year-old has never been able to live up to the hype surrounding him when he first signed from Crystal Palace, and it does appear that it's now time for him to move on.

One weakness in Wan Bissaka's game in which he has seen him lag behind the world's best full-backs is attacking. Diogo Dalot has always been viewed as being much stronger in that area, all be it without the one-on-one defensive abilities of Wan Bissaka.

And if United are in need of a new right-back this summer, then Bayer Leverkusen's Jeremie Frimpong could be the answer. Recent reports from Sky Sports have claimed that the Reds expect offers for Wan Bissaka, with Frimpong viewed as a potential replacement.

The Manchester City academy graduate enjoyed a breakout season at Leverkusen in 2023/24, with his performances playing a key role in their Bundesliga and German Cup wins. Frimpong has emerged as one of the world's best wing-backs under Xabi Alonso and could transform United's attacking output on the right-hand side.

Convincing the 23-year-old to leave a Champions League club will be difficult, although they were able to convince Leny Yoro to join them, despite Lille playing a qualifying tie in August, which will ensure them of a lucrative place in Europe's elite competition.

But if they can sell Wan-Bissaka and have enough money to fund a deal if the player wants to join, then it's a no-brainer for United. Frimpong scored nine goals and provided seven assists, compared to just two assists for Wan-Bissaka last season.

The comparison may not be fair considering how much United as a whole struggled in comparison to Leverkusen enjoying one of the greatest-ever seasons after going unbeaten domestically. But the contrasts are stark, and if Ten Hag's team are going to improve, then adding Frimpong will certainly accelerate that.

headline: Manchester United have a simple Jadon Sancho decision to make after Erik ten Hag U-turn
body: Man United winger Jadon Sancho made his first appearance for the club in almost a year against Rangers, but there are no guarantees it will mark a fresh start.

Those who purchased tickets well in advance for Manchester United's trip to Murrayfield Stadium on Saturday would not have expected a sighting of Jadon Sancho to have been included in the admission price.

After patching things up with Erik ten Hag just over a week earlier, Sancho made his first appearance in a United shirt in 329 days in the Scottish capital. He started on the left of United's front three as goals from Amad and Joe Hugill sealed a 2-0 win over Rangers.

For most, the friendly will not live particularly long in the memory. It was a standard pre-season encounter that featured flashes of quality on what was otherwise a fairly chilled-out afternoon north of the border.

The main talking points, whatever the result, were always going to be Leny Yoro's debut and Sancho's return. Those who attended the Edinburgh clash knew they were in with a chance of catching a glimpse of the duo after they were named in the 26-man travelling squad on Saturday morning.
Sancho was left out of the squad that had travelled to Norway for the pre-season opener against Rosenborg a few days earlier but he was still a topic of conversation.
"As we said, we draw the line," said Ten Hag post-match. "Manchester United need good players and Jadon is a good player. We have drawn that line and we move on."

Sancho was banished from United's first-team squad last September after publicly accusing Ten Hag of lying in a social media post. The whole episode extended from Ten Hag revealing after United's 3-1 defeat to Arsenal at the Emirates Stadium that the winger had been omitted from the squad due to his performance levels in training.

After refusing to apologise for his actions, Sancho was frozen out. He eventually got the chance to get his career back on track in January, rejoining Borussia Dortmund on loan for the remainder of the season.

Sancho's second stint in Germany was not as impressive as some people would have you believe; he scored three goals and registered three assists in 21 appearances. However, he banked credit for helping Dortmund reach the Champions League final.

As a result of Dortmund's run to the showpiece event at Wembley, which they lost 2-0 to Real Madrid, interest in Sancho started to surface. Dortmund quickly admitted they were keen on signing him for a third time and Juventus have been heavily linked. As of Monday morning, Paris Saint-Germain can now be thrown into the mix.

United entered this summer's transfer window with the intention of selling Sancho and ending what has been an unhappy marriage. Since joining the club three years ago, he has struggled for consistency, scoring just 12 goals in 82 games, and has failed to find his feet under three different managers.

United have plenty of options in the wide areas and Sancho has a lot of fighting to do if he is to become an Old Trafford regular again. Alejandro Garnacho is one of United's most important stars and Amad has earned the right to be given a meaningful crack of the whip this season.

Sancho's appearance at Murrayfield should not suddenly change United's plans; they should still be actively looking to sell him. It is likely he will head to the US on the pre-season tour later this week, but that offers no guarantee he will still be a United player by the time the window shuts.

Ten Hag, according to a colleague, did not speak about Sancho with any warmth after the defeat to Rosenborg, suggesting all might not be as rosy as United make out. The club will want to put Sancho back in the limelight as much as possible to try and drive interest and offers.

In a summer where United need to sell to raise funds, they could bank anywhere between £30million and £40m for Sancho, who can still make up for lost time and previous mistakes. It would be in everyone's best interests to part ways.

headline: Manchester United might have a new strongest attack worth £109m for 2024/25 season
body: Man Utd winger Amad ended last season strongly and hit the ground running with his first appearance in pre-season.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Rangers fans would be forgiven for not recognising Amad in the flesh last weekend.
Amad spent the second half of the 2021/22 season on loan with Rangers, but he failed to make an impression at Ibrox Stadium and quietly departed through the back door.

The winger who started against Rangers in a friendly for Manchester United at Murrayfield on Saturday looked like an entirely different player and, just in case their supporters had indeed forgotten who he was, Amad opened the scoring by cutting inside and finding the corner.
Amad produced the only genuine moment of attacking quality in the first half and did brilliantly to create a yard of space before lashing the ball beyond goalkeeper Jack Butland.

Amad was the standout performer for United in the opening 45 minutes - wholesale changes were made at the interval - and had a wide smile, which is now becoming his trademark, when scurrying through the bodies in the corridors of Murrayfield to get on the team bus.
Erik ten Hag was speaking to five Manchester-based reporters when Amad walked past and Jadon Sancho was another to brush past while the United manager was speaking.
Ten Hag had been critical of United after the opening pre-season friendly, but he was content with the victory over Rangers and pleased with Amad's strong performance.

"As you say, he made a very good progression last season," said Ten Hag about Amad. "The past two seasons he was on loan [with Rangers and Sunderland]. and then he was planned to play a role but he had a very bad injury in pre-season that dropped him a little bit back. But in the last games of the season, he showed his assets. Today, this season has to become his season."

Ten Hag was asked whether he sees Amad playing regularly on the right, his preferred position, and replied: "I think that's his best position, but he's capable of playing a lot of positions like the nine, the 10 or from the left wing. He can play all the offensive positions."
Amad might be versatile, but he's most effective when playing on the right and might stake a claim to start in that role when the Premier League season begins on August 16.
The 22-year-old ended last term with a flourish, starting the last three league games, and many believed he was unfortunate to start on the bench in the FA Cup final given his form.
Although a summer break can disrupt a player's momentum, Amad picked up where he left off and there's a feeling that 2024/25 could be his coming-of-age season.

If that proves to be true, Amad will force his way into the starting team and Alejandro Garnacho might be relocated to his favoured position on the left. Garnacho played on the right for the first time against Aston Villa on December 26 and excelled there for the remainder of the season.
Garnacho was brilliant, he scored in the FA Cup final and doesn't deserve to be dropped, so on form, Amad and Garnacho might be the picks to start with Rasmus Hojlund.

That would mean Marcus Rashford would be named on the bench. It still feels like the possibility of Amad and Garnacho starting, with Rashford on the bench, is some way off, but there is an opportunity in the next few weeks of pre-season to sway Ten Hag into a decision.

Rashford wasn't good enough last season, however, Ten Hag is aware of what he's capable of when he's firing and has challenged the forward to return to his best. Whether Rashford can achieve that in the new campaign remains to be seen and Amad could benefit if his slump continues.

United believed they were signing a future star when signing Amad for £19million rising to £37m - a large transfer fee for an 18-year-old who had only played nine times - from Atalanta in 2020 and, a few years after his arrival, he's finally striving to reach his potential at the club.
Amad has taken time to break into the first team and stay there, but the transfer fee he commanded might be considered value at the end of this season if everything goes to plan.
Garnacho was signed for just under £500,000 from Atletico Madrid when he was just a teenager in the summer of 2020 and there's no doubt that fee was a bargain.
Both players could start on the wings next season if everything goes their way.

headline: Leny Yoro makes private feelings clear on Man United transfer after Real Madrid hope
body: Manchester United pulled off one of the coups of the transfer window last week when Lille centre-back Leny Yoro arrived at Old Trafford

Manchester United's new signing, Leny Yoro, has admitted he is relishing the prospect of testing himself in the Premier League after moving to Old Trafford.

On Thursday, the Reds confirmed Yoro would be joining the club for a fee that could rise to £58.9m in the future. The teenager's contract at Lille was set to expire at the end of the upcoming season, which led to plenty of interest in the defender.

Real Madrid were thought to be at the forefront of the race to sign Yoro, but they were pipped to the deal after deciding not to match United's bid. It was reported the 18-year-old had his heart set on moving to the Bernabeu and hoped Los Blancos would come back to the table.

However, if this were the case, he has clearly experienced a change of heart, as Yoro has since spoken passionately about being a United player. In an interview with the club's social media channels, the centre-back expressed his delight at moving to the Theatre of Dreams.
"For me, this is the biggest championship in the world," he explained. "For me, the Premier League, this is where the football fully exists.

"So the fans, the level – because the level is crazy there, there is not an easy game - and, for me, the Premier League is the biggest in the world. This is a historic stage and I'm just really excited to play at Old Trafford, to be honest.
"So, yeah, this is incredible. I already imagined me on the pitch.
"I was with my family there, and they were impressed too. So, yeah, we took a lot of photos.
"It's one of the biggest stadiums in the world. To be honest, I'm really happy to be here. I'm really happy to play for this team and I'm really excited to see you [the fans] in Old Trafford."

headline: What Vanderson has said about Manchester United amid fresh transfer links
body: Man United could be forced into signing a new right-back before the end of this summer's transfer window if Aaron Wan-Bissaka is sold.

AS Monaco right-back Vanderson has previously admitted he was flattered by links connecting him with a move to Manchester United amid fresh suggestions he could be on the move to Old Trafford.

According to Sky Sports, United have included the Brazilian on a list of options to strengthen at right-back if Aaron Wan-Bissaka is sold this summer. The latter is out of contract in just under a year's time, meaning this summer's window represents United's last chance to cash -in for a respectable fee.
He has been heavily linked with West Ham United and a handful of clubs overseas in recent weeks, such as Galatasaray and AC Milan.

Wan-Bissaka, since resurrecting his United career out of nowhere midway through the 2022/23 campaign, has regularly fought with Diogo Dalot for the right-back berth. However, the former's contract situation means Dalot is poised to start the forthcoming season as United's main right-back.

With less than a year remaining on his current deal, it would make sense for United to offload him and avoid the prospect of losing him for free next summer. The club needs to raise funds via player sales and Wan-Bissaka is a sellable asset.

Amid the prospect of him being offloaded, United would have to source a replacement to directly compete with and provide cover for Dalot. The Reds have a long-standing interest in Jeremie Frimpong and have once again been credited with an interest in Vanderson.

The 23-year-old was regularly linked with a move to Old Trafford throughout last summer's transfer window. Wan-Bissaka's comeback, however, meant there was no need for United to draft in another right-back.
Instead, the Brazilian remained in France and chalked up 23 appearances, scoring three goals in the process. He regularly played as an attack-minded wing-back.

headline: 'That is obvious' - Erik ten Hag makes Manchester United transfer demand after Leny Yoro message
body: Man Utd have had a good start to the transfer window and Erik ten Hag is pleased with the business done so far, but wants more additions.

Erik ten Hag praised the new football structure at Old Trafford for their proactive approach to transfers, insisting that is 'what clubs like Manchester United should do'.
United have wrapped up deals for Joshua Zirkzee (£35.7m) and Leny Yoro (£58.9m) already in the transfer window and Ten Hag is pleased to see the structure put in place by Ineos 'on the front foot'.

The deals for Zirkzee and Yoro have solved the two priority positions for the summer, with the latter making his first appearance for the club in Saturday's 2-0 win against Rangers in Murrayfield. Those transfers have been secured under Ineos, with Dan Ashworth in as sporting director, Jason Wilcox as technical director and Christopher Vivell as interim head of recruitment.

United are now in a position where they need to sell to raise funds, with Ten Hag admitting that is a balancing act as he wants a deeper squad this season to deal with an increase in games, with the Europa League group stage now two matches longer. He also wants more quality in the squad and United are continuing to pursue Matthijs de Ligt, while Manuel Ugarte and Martin Zubimendi are two options for a central midfield role.

Another centre-back and a midfielder are likely additions this summer, with one player in those areas likely to be sold. A full-back could also be pursued if Aaron Wan-Bissaka leaves the club, with Premier League interest in the former Crystal Palace right-back.
"Competition, yes, we need quality players. But you also need quantity because the season is even tougher than last season so we have to be ready for that," said Ten Hag.

"That [we need to sell] is also obvious but we want to have a strong squad, as strong as possible. I think at the moment the football leadership is very on the front foot. I think that's what clubs like Manchester United should do.

"We're very pleased we've done business - we have Yoro in, we have Zirkzee in - two high potential assets for the future. But when I say future, the future also starts today. The next game is always the most important, next season is always the most important."

The deals concluded so far show an emphasis on youth, with 23-year-old Zirkzee and Yoro only 18, although the teenager looked ready to play a prominent role in his 45-minute appearance at Murrayfield. Ten Hag was pleased with his performance after just one training session with his new teammates and sent a message to United's more experienced centre-halves that he believes the youngster is ready to play a key role at the heart of defence this season.
"He's here, we think he can play but there's so many games to come that he'll be in a group of four or five," he said.

"I think for the first time, after just one training [session], it's a very mature performance. That's what we saw when we scouted him. It's great to have him. He's a very young, talented centre-back and there's a lot to come."

Manchester City weren't at their best for their last game of the season and neither will they for the first game of the new season.

Tired for the FA Cup Final against Manchester United at Wembley in May, Pep Guardiola's side will not have had much time together at all when they head down to London in August to play...Manchester United at Wembley. City do not have the best record in the Community Shield - they have the lost the last three in a row - in part because it is used as preparations for more important competitions.

That said, it can still serve as a valuable springboard - particularly for youngsters. Cole Palmer and Sam Edozie have used the Wembley showpiece to progress their careers, while even an appearance in the squad can be useful.

This summer, with a host of absences on their pre-season tour owing to commitments at the European Championship, Copa America and Olympics, up to four youngsters look to have a chance of making Guardiola's squad in under three weeks in a game that will raise the curtain on the new campaign.

Eight senior players confirmed to be in the United States for the tour will, barring injuries or transfers, all make up part of the 20-man squad against United. Ederson, Stefan Ortega, Josko Gvardiol, Rico Lewis, Mateo Kovacic, Oscar Bobb, Jack Grealish and Erling Haaland are all expected to be there.

Another eight will return to Manchester in the week of the Community Shield and have a decent chance of featuring. New signing Savinho joins those players who were knocked out before the final of the European Championship: Ruben Dias, Nathan Ake, Manu, Akanji, Matheus Nunes, Bernardo Silva, Kevin De Bruyne, and Jeremy Doku.

There are another four - Kyle Walker, John Stones, Phil Foden, and Rodri - who went as far as the final with their national teams whose return is yet to be confirmed. They could make it in time for the Community Shield but nobody would be bothered if they took up an offer of extra rest ahead of a gruelling season.

That offers a door into Wembley for some of the young players currently on tour with Guardiola. Whatever else they can get from two weeks of training with the first team, the chance of making the Community Shield squad is a tantalising reward in sight.

Kalvin Phillips could be part of that group if he is still at the club by then, although the midfielder is looking for another move after a disastrous two years at the Etihad. Maximo Perrone, Callum Doyle, and Tom Galvez are all expected to secure loans.

From the rest, holding midfielders Jacob Wright and Mahamadou Susoho are well-placed as cover for Rodri while further up the pitch James McAtee and Micah Hamilton are both hoping to kick on this year. Then there are more wildcard options, from promising playmaker Nico O'Reilly to 16-year-old centre-back Stephen Mfuni.
Guardiola has made it clear that he doesn't hand out appearances in his squad as presents, but there is room for a few youngsters to do enough in the US to earn their place at Wembley.

Signing another forward and bolstering the defensive ranks were United's main priorities this summer. Of course, he was on loan at Old Trafford last season and United held an option (not obligation) to make that deal permanent despite the Moroccan World Cup hero already returning to Fiorentina. A presumably four-way decision, then, with pros and cons to each option - and Zubimendi somewhat a wildcard choice.

headline: Erik ten Hag performed Man Utd transfer U-turn after Jude Bellingham's four-word comment
body: Jude Bellingham enjoyed a phenomenal first season with Real Madrid - but the England star was linked with a move to Manchester United last summer before his switch to the Santiago Bernabeu
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Erik ten Hag was forced to perform a U-turn in Manchester United's pursuit of Jude Bellingham after the Real Madrid star played down rumours of an Old Trafford move as "silly".

It’s difficult to picture Bellingham playing anywhere but Real Madrid after his ground-breaking debut season in Spain. Having made the move from Borussia Dortmund last summer, the 21-year-old is already an iconic figure at the Santiago Bernabeu.

Bellingham's impressive tally of 23 goals across all competitions was instrumental in driving Real Madrid to both the league title and European glory, establishing himself as one of football's preeminent stars. Yet, only a year ago, his future was the subject of speculation, with clubs from around Europe circling Dortmund's Westfalenstadion in the hope they could get their clutches on England’s biggest star.

Manchester United were among those fighting for his signature, with Ten Hag desperate to fill the void left by Paul Pogba's departure the previous year. In a rare public display by a manager at the top level, Ten Hag openly expressed his desire to land Bellingham in April 2023.
When prompted by a fan outside United's training ground to sign Kylian Mbappe and Bellingham, he responded with a smile, saying: "Why not?" before driving off.

That was despite Bellingham openly rejecting United in a video uploaded on social media just a month prior. The Euro 2024 superstar was asked: “Are you gonna come Man U?” while taking a photo with a fan, before chuckling and responding: "No. Don't be silly."

It became clear in the following months that Bellingham’s preferred destination was the Spanish capital, prompting United to cool their interest while Ten Hag grew frustrated. And yet it wasn't the first time United had faced rejection from Bellingham in his nascent career.

His rise at Birmingham City didn’t go unnoticed by the Red Devils, who under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer went to great lengths to woo the young talent. They arranged a face-to-face meeting with Sir Alex Ferguson and a tour of the training ground led by former football director John Murtough.

Bellingham would fatefully turn down United in favour of immediate first-team chances at Dortmund. Four years on, he is in contention for the Ballon d'Or alongside world-class players such as Rodri and Vinicius Junior, while United recorded their worst Premier League finish last season in eighth place.

Manchester United are working on a deal to sign Arsenal youth striker Chido Obi-Martin this summer.
Obi-Martin, 16, is set to leave Arsenal's academy and he visited Carrington earlier in the week ahead of a potential to switch to United, which would be seen as a coup.

The Manchester Evening News understands United are hopeful of completing a deal for Obi-Martin, who would be given a scholarship with an agreement to sign a professional contract, if he decides to join the club and turn down interest from Bayern Munich and Newcastle.
Obi-Martin scored 29 goals in 17 league matches for Arsenal's Under-18s last season and he's considered among the brightest prospects in youth football.
The youngster has decided to leave London and that comes as a blow to Arsenal, who are understood to have offered what they believed were fair terms to safeguard his future.
Denmark-born Obi-Martin joined Arsenal from Danish team KB in 2022 and went from strength to strength last season, notably scoring 10 goals in a single game against Liverpool.
Obi-Martin has been a youth international for Denmark and England, but he represented Denmark in the UEFA European Under-17 Championship qualification campaign this year.

United are always on the lookout to add the best-emerging talent to their academy - Brexit also impacted which youngsters they can sign - and completing a deal for the exciting Obi-Martin would be a further signal of the club's intent to be best in class in youth football.
Obi-Martin will celebrate his 17th birthday in November - the age when professional contracts can be signed - and will join up with United's U18s if signing for the club.

headline: Manchester United have five academy stars who could cause a shock in pre-season
body: Man Utd have a wonderful record of developing young players and some academy talents will play on the tour of the USA.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
For any youngster at Manchester United, the opportunity to travel on a pre-season summer tour and rub shoulders with senior players is an unforgettable experience.

United have travelled overseas during pre-season since Sir Alex Ferguson's reign - aside from when Covid restrictions didn't allow it - and the Reds have received incredible support everywhere they have travelled.

There have been trips to nearby Scotland and Ireland, and longer haul journies to Scandinavia, Asia and North America. Arranging pre-season fixtures around the world gives United's global following an opportunity to see the team in the flesh but they are also commercially lucrative.
The Premier League's elite sides have made regular trips to the United States in recent years and United will visit Los Angeles, San Diego and Columbia this summer.
Erik ten Hag oversaw United's pre-season preparation in the States last year and named a 31-man travelling squad, which included Kobbie Mainoo, Omari Forson and Dan Gore.

Mainoo became a first-team star in the following season. Gore was given his senior debut in September and Forson was handed his senior bow in January, which showed that the youngsters included on the USA tour in 2023 were highly regarded by Ten Hag and his staff.

The crop of youngsters selected for the first-team squad for an overseas tour is usually a strong indicator of the manager's plans and it will be fascinating to see which academy players make the cut this summer.

United have been at the forefront of youth development for decades and they continue to produce talent. Alejandro Garnacho and Mainoo are the most recent success stories from the youth set-up and it's understood academy staff are confident more senior debuts will follow.
The milestone of the 250th player from United's academy to make a first-team debut was reached last season and that was a magnificent achievement worth celebrating.

Ethan Wheatley's name was written into the club's history books when he became the 250th graduate thanks to his cameo from the bench against Sheffield United in April. The young striker replaced Rasmus Hojlund in that game and savoured every minute on the pitch.

After the match, Wheatley spoke to MUTV and he had to fight the smile on his face while he answered questions. "It's a great club with a massive history, especially in the academy. It's an honour to make my debut and that number - 250. That's a little bit extra," he said.
"I was just excited and when I got the call [to come on], there were a bit of nerves, but as soon as I was stripped and ready to go I was excited and did my best for the team."
Wheatley was given the nickname '250' by his teammates in the academy and his debut capped a whirlwind 24 hours, in which he also fired the Under-18s to a trophy.
On the day before Wheatley's senior debut at Old Trafford, he scored a first-half brace for the U18s in a cup final against rivals Manchester City at Leigh Sports Village.

Wheatley was substituted at half-time so he could be involved with the first team the next day. Wayne Rooney was in attendance at Leigh and the United legend would have enjoyed what he saw, as Wheatley's goals were smartly taken and they were enough to win the trophy.
There is more to come from Wheatley, who has already looked sharp in pre-season, and he's got an excellent chance of being included in the touring squad of the USA.

The same can be said about Toby Collyer. The midfielder had the privilege of wearing the captain's armband in the second half of the opening pre-season clash against Rosenborg and there have been a few clues along his journey that suggest he's well regarded by Ten Hag.
Collyer was named on the bench eight times last season and although he didn't make the squad for the FA Cup final, he travelled to Wembley and was on the pitch at the final whistle.
Once the initial celebrations died down, Ten Hag was spotted in deep conversation with Collyer and he had a similar moment with Mainoo after the Carabao Cup final in 2023.

Whether Collyer can have the impact in the first team Mainoo did remains to be seen - the Stockport-born youngster is an exceptional prospect and was superb for England at Euro 2024 - but it seemed significant that Ten Hag took extra time to speak to him.
There was a further clue when Collyer was rewarded with a new deal in July that extended his stay until 2027 and Ten Hag insisted on attending his contract signing.
A club source said Ten Hag 'really likes' Collyer, who is yet to make his senior debut, and it's highly likely he will be included in the pre-season travelling squad.
United lost their opening friendly against Rosenorg 1-0 and Ten Hag was scathing with criticism after the game, but he couldn't be disappointed with the performance of Radek Vitek.
Vitek travelled to America last summer and could fly across the pond again, despite United having Andre Onana, Tom Heaton and Altay Bayindir in their goalkeeping ranks.
The 20-year-old stands at a towering 6ft 6ins and he made an outstanding impression against Rosenborg, making multiple key saves and delivering a man-of-the-match display.
Vitek performed like Peter Schmeichel in his prime and was only denied a clean sheet, which he deserved, in the final minutes when Rosenborg scored with an unstoppable effort.

Vitek spent last term on loan with Accrington Stanley and that spell was considered a huge success due to the experience he gained and the volume of matches he played, but he's expected to play in a higher division next season and perhaps a Championship loan could come next.
The young 'keeper was brilliant in the successful FA Youth Cup campaign of 2021/22 - Mainoo and Garnacho were in that team - and seems like a prospect worth keeping an eye on.
Elsewhere, Harry Amass has a chance of making the USA squad after a superb season with the U18s, who won a stunning treble and claimed two of those trophies at the expense of City.
Amass took part in first-team training in February when he was just 16 years old and he signed his first professional contract a month later when he celebrated his birthday.

The left-back signed for United from Watford in 2023. Amass is considered one of the most exciting talents in English football and, although he still has scope to develop physically, Ten Hag trusted him enough to include him in matchday squads at the end of last season.
A young player who has an outside chance of making the squad is Jack Fletcher, the talented son of former United player Darren Fletcher, who is now part of Ten Hag's coaching staff.
Sources at United believe Fletcher has first-team potential and while his progress was briefly delayed last season due to an injury, he's now back to full fitness again.
United's tour of the USA is upon us and fans should closely follow which youngsters are included. They could be starring for the first team before you know it.

Talented young forward Chido Obi-Martin has been linked with a move to Manchester United after his terms with Arsenal expired.

The 16-year-old made headlines in April after netting seven goals in a stunning 9-0 victory for the Gunners' under-18s team. Obi-Martin scored 32 goals in total at U18s level for Arsenal, including five against West Ham United, four against Crystal Palace and another four against Fulham.

In achieving this, Obi-Martin has surpassed Folarin Balogun's record of most goals scored for Arsenal U18s in a season, previously set at 25 during the 2018/19 campaign. And the Athletic reports that United are exploring a deal with the player said to have visited United’s Carrington training facilities earlier this week. Manchester City are also said to be interested.

The teenager, who also managed to score an impressive ten goals in a 14-3 victory over Liverpool's under-16s back in November, has represented Arsenal in UEFA Youth League matches against Sevilla and Lens, and has made two substitute appearances at Premier League 2 level.

Born in 2007 in Glostrup, on the outskirts of Copenhagen, the Danish youngster moved to the UK as a teenager. He has represented both England and Denmark's national teams at youth level and is also eligible to play for Nigeria, reports football.london.
However, it currently seems more likely that he will represent Denmark, having recently scored ten times in 14 games for their Under-17s, including four in a 6-2 win against Norway.

International head coach Jesper Mikkelsen, spoke to Bold (via Tribal Football) and outlined the extraordinary abilities of the Arsenal forward. "Right now he is really dominant because of his physique, but I don't think that is the only reason," claimed Mikkelsen.
"His greatest characteristic and challenge is that he really wants to score goals."

He added that this focus on goal-scoring could be a double-edged sword: "When I say it can also be a disadvantage, I mean that he can sometimes play his own game. He is very searching for chances, where he forgets that you also have to play with the others."

Whether Obi-Martin decides to stick with Denmark or switches allegiance to England or Nigeria, his recent impressive exploit would only ignite further interest in his potential. Arsenal's legend Ian Wright recently sang the young player's praises, noting: "Chido Obi-Martin, he's 15, honestly, he's like 6 foot 2, he looks really quick."

Manchester United youngsters Ashton Missin, Jacob Devaney and Tom Myles have signed their first professional contracts with the club.
United's Under-18s enjoyed a stunning season in the 2023/24, completing a treble and winning two of those trophies at the expense of rivals Manchester City.

Last season's U18 side were supremely talented and they have been compared to the FA Youth Cup winning squad of 2022, which included the likes of Alejandro Garnacho, Kobbie Mainoo, Willy Kambwala and Dan Gore.
Some of the U18 stars from last term have already been given professional contracts, which can only be signed once a player is 17, and United have handed out more deals this week.

Missin, who played on the left and right wing last season, has been given his first professional contract and he contributed four goals and two assists in the league. The 17-year-old was born in Halifax and is making up for lost time having been sidelined in 2022/23 with injury.
Devaney celebrated his 17th birthday last month, his natural position is defensive midfielder and he played 22 of a possible 24 games in the U18s' league campaign.
He was born in Yorkshire and his father, Martin Devaney, is the assistant coach at League One club Barnsley. Devaney qualifies to play for the Republic of Ireland through his grandparents.
Myles, who is a goalkeeper, made important saves on the way to the U18s' league triumph and kept eight clean sheets in 19 league appearances
The Manchester Evening News also understands Jack Kingdon, who impressed by delivering consistently strong displays for the U18s, has signed his first professional contract.
Kingdon, who has featured in Scotland's youth ranks (eligible through his father), trained with the first-team for the first time in April and captained the U18s on a few occasions.
Ethan Williams contributed 17 goals and nine assists in academy fixtures last season and his pre-agreed professional contract was activated this summer.

headline: Dan Ashworth makes reassuring Manchester United promise after Sir Jim Ratcliffe controversy
body: Man United officially appointed Dan Ashworth as sporting director at the start of this month after lengthy negotiations
